headline: Ex-Man Utd boss Ralf Rangnick 'needs further hospital treatment' after surgery
body: Ralf Rangnick is being treated in hospital and in need of further treatment after contracting an infection following ankle surgeries, say reports in Germany.

The former Manchester United interim manager, 67, has undergone multiple surgeries on his ankle in recent months. And the Austria national team has now contracted a 'hospital-acquired germ' after his latest surgery in Murnau, Bavaria, last week.

Complications from ankle surgery and the subsequent infection means Rangnick will now remain in hospital for an extended period. He initially underwent ankle surgery in June but was forced to undergo an emergency operation due to complications in July. His ankle issues saw him undergo another operation last week, with Bild saying Rangnick's infection is the 'serious reason' behind his extended stay in hospital.
Johannes Gabel, an ankle specialist who has worked with some of Germany's top stars including Manuel Neuer and Jamal Musiala, will oversee Rangnick's further treatment.
Rangnick's situation means he has been forced to pull out of the upcoming Austria squad announcement on September 29 ahead of their World Cup qualifiers against San Marino and Romania next month.
He is expected, though, to be back on the touchline for those games. Rangnick's assistant, Lars Kornetka, will now announce the squad for those games.

Rangnick had a brief stint as United's manager between December 2021 and May 2022 after the club decided to part company with Ole Gunnar Solskjaer, winning 11 of the 29 matches he oversaw before the Red Devils appointed Erik ten Hag.

Rangnick had initially signed up to take on a consultancy role at the club following his spell in the dugout. However, it was decided he would leave Old Trafford shortly after agreeing a two-year contract to become the new head coach of the Austria national team.

headline: Why Man United will wear unique kit against Brentford due to Premier League rule
body: Manchester United are set to return to Premier League action this Saturday, as they head to the Gtech Community Stadium to face Brentford. After a sluggish start to the 2025/26 season, the Red Devils will be hoping their recent victory over Chelsea at Old Trafford signals a change in fortune.

Bruno Fernandes and Casemiro found the back of the net after Robert Sanchez was given his marching orders early in the match. Ruben Amorim's squad will be making the journey to London for the weekend's early kick-off, with their sights set on securing their first win at Brentford since January 2022.

Those tuning in or attending the match will notice a slight change in United's appearance. For the first time this season, United will be donning their black third kit. Up until now, they've sported their red home shirt in all six competitive matches, with the white away kit only making an appearance during pre-season.
The third kit, with its black base, features yellow and blue accents, paying homage to the away kit worn from 1993 to 1995.
However, for the Brentford match, United will be sporting a unique kit to adhere to regulations regarding kit clashes.
Typically, the kit would consist of black shirts and shorts to match.
But due to Brentford's black shorts and socks, the Reds will be pulling on yellow socks for this particular match.
Arsenal had to make a similar kit adjustment last week when they faced Athletic Club in the Champions League.
The Gunners' away strip, which is predominantly dark blue and black, including the shorts and socks, clashed with Athletic's home kit, forcing them to switch to white shorts and socks.

The Premier League regulations stipulate that "when playing in league matches the players of each participating club shall wear a strip which is of a sufficient contrast that match officials, spectators and television viewers will be able to distinguish clearly between the two teams."

headline: Police launch investigation after Man Utd fan attacked following social media stunt
body: Greater Manchester Police have confirmed they are investigating after a Manchester United supporter who has gone viral on social media for vowing not to cut his hair until the club win five games in a row was assaulted at the weekend.

Frank Ilett, who has gained over 374,000 followers on his 'The United Strand' Instagram account, announced last year that he would not be chopping his locks until the Red Devils chalk up five successive wins. He has since appeared on podcasts, radio shows and his posts have been shared all over social media after going over 350 days without a haircut due to United's poor form.

However, things turned sour at the weekend when he was grabbed by the hair by a man who seemed to be a fellow fan during Saturday evening's 2-1 win over Chelsea. The man can be heard yelling: "F*** off, I'll do what I f***ing want" and "he's not a United f***ing fan" whilst lunging forwards in front of spectators on the Old Trafford concourse, including youngsters, in a video which has been widely shared on social media.

It has now been confirmed that both Manchester United and Greater Manchester Police are probing the incident. A spokesperson for GMP said: "We are fully aware of this incident and the investigation is ongoing in conjunction with Manchester United.
"The victim has been contacted and enquiries are ongoing to identify the offender."

"I have of course been a Man United fan my entire life and my intention with this challenge was never to highlight Man United's flaws. It was all a bit weird to be honest. I will always try to focus on the positives and hope that this was just a one off.
"I thought he was just joking to start with, but then he started yanking my hair and calling me an 'attention seeking c**t'.
"The whole day was full of hundreds of positive interactions yesterday and 99 per cent of all of the reactions to this challenge have been nice. But just a few people can ruin it!
"Like I've said before, I never expected it to go on for so long, but I'm hopeful we can go on a good run soon and I, more than most... want these wins to come as soon as possible."

headline: Manchester United stars react to Ousmane Dembele Ballon d'Or triumph over Mohamed Salah
body: Manchester United pair Bryan Mbeumo and Leny Yoro have responded to Paris Saint-Germain winger Ousmane Dembele claiming the Ballon d'Or following intense competition. The France star triumphed over challengers including Lamine Yamal, Vitinha, and Mohamed Salah to secure the prize and earn recognition as Europe's best male footballer.
Liverpool's Salah claimed fourth spot in the final standings. The Egyptian was crowned PFA Premier League player of the year for 2024/25 following his role in Liverpool's title triumph.

Other Premier League representatives Cole Palmer (Chelsea) and Gianluigi Donnarumma (Man City) placed eighth and ninth, respectively, whilst ex-Man United midfielder Scott McTominay secured 18th position.
Dembele netted 21 times and registered eight assists across 29 Ligue 1 outings for PSG during the previous campaign. He also played a crucial part as they claimed their maiden Champions League crown.

Across his 15 European appearances, he found the net eight times and contributed six assists, including two in their commanding 5-0 triumph over Inter in May's showpiece. The 28-year-old looked visibly moved whilst receiving the Ballon d'Or award on stage.
Taking to social media afterwards, he posted images alongside the trophy with a message reading: "So much joy, pride, and emotion.
"A dream come true. Thank you to everyone who has always supported me along this journey."
Mbeumo, the United forward, was among those offering their congratulations, sharing one of Dembele's photos on his Instagram story with a raising hands and tearful emoji.
United defender Leny Yoro also joined in to celebrate his compatriot's achievement, reposting Dembele's update with the caption "Amazing bro," accompanied by a clapping red heart emoji.

Dembele's social media post garnered 'likes' from both current and former United players, including Bruno Fernandes, Joshua Zirkzee, and Manuel Ugarte. Marcus Rashford, currently on loan at Barcelona from United, also showed his support by 'liking' the post.

headline: Man Utd take action after backlash to Amad’s Alejandro Garnacho message
body: Manchester United have reached out to offer Amad support after he was on the receiving end of online abuse over the weekend. Amad deleted all his Instagram posts after United fans criticised his decision to share a photo of himself with Alejandro Garnacho.

The United winger posted a photo of himself posing with Garnacho's Chelsea shirt alongside his former team-mate, who was holding up his United shirt. The meeting between the two came after United beat Chelsea 2-1 at Old Trafford in the Premier League on Saturday.

Although he didn't get onto the pitch after Robert Sanchez's early red card for Chelsea, it was Garnacho's first trip back to his former club following a £40million transfer in the summer. Amad is friends with the Argentina international, who is also represented by the same agency, but the post did not go down well with fans.

The 23-year-old was abused by some supporters and reacted by deleting all his Instagram posts and all but one of his posts on X. The Sun reports that United checked on him on Monday and offered support.

Despite his reaction to the backlash, Amad is understood to be okay. After playing the full 90 minutes against Chelsea, he will be hoping to keep his place in the side for when United travel to face Brentford in the league on Saturday.

United have a full week to prepare for the trip to west London, having already been knocked out of the Carabao Cup. While most Premier League sides are involved in the third round competition in midweek, United were beaten on penalties by Grimsby Town in the second round in August.

Amad has featured in all six of their matches so far this season, starting all but one fixture. He has so far contributed just one assist for the struggling side, who sit 11th in the Premier League following their second win of the campaign on the weekend.

Garnacho left United under a cloud in the summer after falling out with Amorim in the final few games of last season. The 21-year-old was told he had no future at the club and became a part of the 'bomb squad', forced to train with fellow exiles Marcus Rashford, Jadon Sancho, Antony and Tyrell Malacia.

Garnacho was only made two brief substitute appearances for Chelsea so far, against Brentford and Bayern Munich, and stayed on the bench at Old Trafford following Sanchez's early red card for denying a goalscoring opportunity.

headline: Sir Alex Ferguson stopped Man Utd players shouting at each other after storming down team bus
body: Manchester United legend Sir Alex Ferguson was known for his strict discipline, and it seems that even video games on the team bus weren't safe from his wrath. The insight comes from former Red Devil Paul Scholes, who shared the anecdote on The Good, The Bad and The Football podcast with Paddy McGuinness and fellow ex-United star Nicky Butt.

The conversation started when McGuinness mentioned a tale told by Old Trafford icon Wayne Rooney. The club's record goal scorer suggested that part of United's incredible success during his time at the club was due to the bonds formed while playing video games on the team coach.
A number of United players, including Rio Ferdinand, John O'Shea and Wes Brown, would participate in sessions of SOCOM on the PlayStation Portable.
However, despite Rooney's assertions, these gaming gatherings didn't sit well with Sir Alex, who was famed for his iron-fisted leadership.
When quizzed about Rooney's comments, Scholes said: "I didn't play those games, it was more the younger lads in the group.

"The PSP (the PlayStation Portable) and SOCOM, and I can hear them all f*****g shouting from the back of the bus, and it's sort some of shooting game, a war game, and it's all you could hear and it was f*****g annoying."
McGuinness chimed in, asserting that bus journeys to and from matches were usually filled with card games rather than video games.

Scholes added: "I do remember the boss going down the back of the bus saying, 'Shut the f**k up - because they're all shouting at each other, 'We're on our way to Arsenal away here, what's wrong with you?'".

However, he did admit that there might have been some camaraderie benefits from the group gaming, saying: "Sometimes it's quite funny as they are having a right go at each other at the back and there is a bit of camaraderie and it's a team game as well."
"I really believe a big part of our success was playing on the PSP," said Rooney. "It got us communicating more - we used to play it on the plane, on the team bus.

"It would be me, Rio [Ferdinand], Michael Carrick, John O'Shea, Wes Brown. You have to talk, you have to tactically be right, go and revive people when they get killed and it was a massive part of our success - ask any of those players, it was brilliant."

headline: Man United sent transfer warning as Scott McTominay Ballon d'Or ranking speaks volumes
body: Manchester United demonstrated this summer that there are times when a sale is necessary, regardless of whether the deal is ideal for the club or not. Alejandro Garnacho had to be sold in the last transfer window as his relationship with the club was causing more harm than good.

Marcus Rashford was a similar case, albeit to a lesser extent as it seemed he may not have completely severed all ties, but based on the evidence, it was still right to let him go. In retrospect, the Reds made a terrible mistake in letting Scott McTominay leave the football club.
Like Garnacho and Rashford, United profited from the deal, making the books look healthier once he departed for Napoli. However, unlike his former teammates, McTominay was not a problem at United.

His previous manager Erik ten Hag even expressed regret at letting the Scottish international go. Ten Hag hastily decided that he needed to bolster defensive midfield but instead of trying to offload Casemiro, who remains one of the highest paid players at the club, he sold an asset who is now taking the football world by storm.

Remarkably, in his first season in Serie A, McTominay managed to flourish more than anyone anticipated. His tally of 12 goals and six assists marked the best season of his professional career, proving instrumental in Antonio Conte's side clinching the Serie A title.

However, his redemption arc was only fully realised on Monday night when he ranked 18th in the Ballon d'Or standings, ahead of Jude Bellingham, Erling Haaland, Declan Rice and Florian Wirtz. And let's not forget, there wasn't a single United player to be found anywhere near the Top 30.

At the time, the decision to sell McTominay seemed like a short-term move that hadn't been thoroughly thought through. While no one could have predicted his sensational season in Italy, the 28-year-old's story should serve as a warning for United's future decisions.

History already seems set to repeat itself under Ruben Amorim, with Kobbie Mainoo's future looking increasingly uncertain. He requested a loan move in the summer, which was rejected, and so far, there's little indication that United will be able to satisfy his concerns before the January transfer window opens.

If Mainoo were to 'do a McTominay', he would be better positioned to succeed given his younger age and less inconsistent form at Old Trafford. Failing to address Mainoo's concerns though could once again lead United to make a short-term decision that ultimately hampers the club's long-term progression.
Mainoo is keen to remain with United, which is why he only requested a loan move. However, the rigid adherence to captain Bruno Fernandes could push him towards a permanent exit.

Fernandes' contribution to the team is undeniable, but there's a real chance he could depart next summer. If Mainoo has already been forced out by then, United could find themselves in a tricky situation where they have to replace both men.
Amorim needs to start grooming Mainoo now to be Fernandes' successor. It's clear that he has the talent for it, and United is a club known for giving young players a chance.

If United are to learn anything from McTominay's success, it should be that sometimes it's better to nurture the next generation from within rather than selling them off for quick cash. If Mainoo does leave, it would demonstrate that the Reds haven't learned their lesson, at all.

headline: Man United plot double transfer decision as talks held with £65m boost
body: Manchester United are reportedly eyeing up a new shot-stopper, despite the recent acquisition of Senne Lammens from Royal Antwerp for a cool £18.2million plus add-ons. The Belgian is yet to feature for Ruben Amorim's squad with Altay Bayindir preferred.

The 23-year-old has already made his presence known on the bench during the Manchester derby, but head coach Ruben Amorim insists there's no guaranteed number one keeper in his squad. "No, nobody has a place that is his place," he responded when quizzed about whether Bayindir was his first choice following Andre Onana's loan move to Trabzonspor.
"Everyone has to fight. Everyone is fighting for a place. I'm just trying to win games, trying to see what is the best option to win the next game."

Despite Bayindir starting every Premier League match so far, he's yet to fully win over the coaching staff. Prior to signing Lammens, United had reportedly agreed personal terms with World Cup winner Emiliano Martinez of Aston Villa, but ultimately opted for the Belgian.

Chelsea attempted to snap him up in the summer with a £12million bid, falling short of Milan's £21million asking price. It's understood that United bigwigs have recently been in talks with Maignan's representatives, who also manage £65million summer signing Bryan Mbeumo.

Alongside a new shot-stopper, United are also looking to splash the cash on a midfielder. Brighton and Hove Albion's Carlos Baleba is reportedly on their radar, especially with Casemiro's contract due to run out next year.

Kobbie Mainoo's future at the club is also currently uncertain after failing to break into Amorim's plans. The England international has been used mainly off the bench this season and has been linked with a move away.

headline: Marcus Rashford warned over Barcelona punishment as Man Utd transfer agreement uncertain
body: Marcus Rashford has been told that Barcelona were absolutely right to discipline him for reportedly arriving late to a pre-match meeting, with his behaviour being slammed as "disrespectful". The on-loan Manchester United forward began last week brilliantly with a spectacular two-goal display for the La Liga club away to Newcastle in the Champions League.

But the 27-year-old found himself relegated to the substitutes' bench for Barcelona's 3-0 victory over Getafe on Sunday after widespread reports in Spain claimed he arrived two minutes late to a team briefing. Ex-United and Wrexham shot-stopper Ben Foster has now cautioned Rashford that his conduct is "not good enough" whilst supporting Barca boss Hansi Flick's uncompromising stance on punctuality.

It follows the Mirror reporting that the two clubs remain significantly apart regarding an agreement on the transfer fee needed to make the England international's loan switch permanent. Barcelona are believed to be eager to sign Rashford at a knockdown price of £26million, whilst United are hoping to secure closer to £35m for their academy product.
Foster voiced his frustration over Rashford's latest indiscretion, despite lauding him for recapturing his best form in the Newcastle clash.
Speaking on his Fozcast podcast, he said: "Rashford got a couple of goals, it was a fantastic performance and he just looked proper. It was old school Marcus Rashford and we love to see it.

"Then he goes and gets dropped at the weekend because he was late for a team stretching session on the morning of a game. The way that Barcelona have dealt with it, you can tell Hansi Flick doesn't take any s***."

Foster later added: "It's disrespectful and I understand people going, 'Oh, he's [only] a minute or two late,' but it doesn't matter. There are 29 other people there who are waiting for you. If you can't get the basics right, then it's not good enough."

Rashford isn't the only player to fall foul of Flick's strict discipline code, with Jules Kounde, Inaki Pena, and most recently Raphinha all facing sanctions for similar infractions. Rashford was expected to start the Getafe clash on the left flank of Barcelona's attack, but Ferran Torres was selected in his place.

Despite being left out, he displayed no visible signs of annoyance and entered the fray to replace Raphinha at the interval. Rashford shone on the right wing, setting up Dani Olmo's decisive third goal that sealed victory.
Rashford is spending the campaign on loan at Barca after falling out with United boss Ruben Amorim. He spent the latter half of last term on loan at Aston Villa before switching to the Nou Camp.

He has featured six times so far and opened his account against Newcastle last week. No recall provision exists in the loan deal between United and Barca, with the Catalan giants holding an option to secure his services permanently next summer.

headline: Unai Emery tipped to replace Ruben Amorim at Man Utd after bombshell Aston Villa exit
body: Former Aston Villa star Stan Collymore has predicted Manchester United will soon be 'sniffing around' Unai Emery to replace Ruben Amorim. Current Red Devils boss Ruben Amorim is feeling the heat after a dismal start to the season - the club's worst since the 1992/93 campaign.

Currently languishing in 11th place in the Premier League, United also suffered an embarrassing League Cup defeat at the hands of Grimsby Town. The club's rocky start follows a disappointing 15th place finish last season - their lowest in the Premier League era.

Adding insult to injury, they were defeated by Tottenham Hotspur in the Europa League final in May, meaning Old Trafford has no European football for the first time in over 10 years. With Amorim's position becoming increasingly precarious, it's no surprise that some of Europe's top managerial talent are being linked with the job.

One such name is Villa's Emery, who was rumoured to be in the frame during Erik ten Hag's troubled tenure at United last year. Despite a slow start to the season with Villa, Emery's work in Birmingham has been widely lauded.

His potential departure from Villa Park seems more plausible following the exit of the club's President of Football Operations, Monchi, on Monday, as he and Emery have been closely associated. Now, Collymore has weighed in on the unexpected news from his old club.

"Monchi. Lots of social media with others in recruitment about how hard they worked (so do others, especially Brighton and Bournemouth) which struck a chord with Villans as the going was good," he said via X (Twitter).

"But I make it three resounding successes in the market (players who play for the first team, not jiggery pokery for PSR) in Tielemans, Rogers and Pau out of a 20+ incoming of players. That's average recruitment at best. Emery wanted him and this now raises the question as to whether Unai's tenure will now grind to an end of season halt (*fires starting pistol on speculation every week about United, etc etc etc) or whether Unai has agreed with my analysis, biffed off a great friend but "business is business" and a new shiny recruitment guy comes in with a better strike rate.

"Said on here a few weeks back that recruitment at a club like Villa has to be at 80+% success rate in order to compete so that's the task for the new person. I hope Emery strikes up a rapport with someone new and gets his mojo back, doubles down and commits to the long haul.

"He's not of our neck of the woods though, he'll have suitors in Spain, probably one or two big Italian clubs and should United be serious about change then they'll have a sniff too, why wouldn't they, they can offer almost unlimited resources to back up what Villa did last season with multiple seasons of serious cash support.

"The next 48 hours will tell everything. If he's bullish and wants to stay, you'll see it as he's a straight talker. If he doesn't look at the camera, fidgits with his ear and doesn't answer 'do you see your long term at Villa?' then the owners and new recruitment guy need to get a list together quickly in case he exits sooner or end of season. Hope for the best, plan for the worst. UP THE RECRUITMENTLESS VILLA."

headline: Ruben Amorim's Man Utd tactics brutally called out – 'I would've hated this'
body: Rio Ferdinand has slammed Ruben Amorim for his constant rotation of the Manchester United centre-backs during games. During the 2-1 victory over Chelsea, Amorim's decision to switch up his defence nearly cost them as a late goal gave the Blues hope and set up a tense finish.

The Old Trafford side had been leading 2-0 after Robert Sanchez was sent off in the fifth minute, with goals from Bruno Fernandes and Casemiro. However, Casemiro was also shown a red card just before half time, and Trevoh Chalobah capitalised on some slack defending to head home with 10 minutes left.

United's weakness at set pieces is well-known, with much of the blame being placed on their goalkeepers, Altay Bayindir and Andre Onana, who is currently on loan at Trabzonspor until the end of the season.

But Ferdinand has admitted that the changing of the defensive line will not be helping United's cause. Speaking on his podcast Rio Presents', Ferdinand expressed his frustration at Amorim's constant changes in defence.
He posted a clip of the podcast on X with the caption: "Why do we keep changing our centre backs during the game?! I WOULD HAVE HATED THIS!"

On the podcast, he said: "I look at teams that win, right? Whether it's my team, whether it's the old Ruben Amorim teams with Tony Adams or with Martin Keown, Sol Campbell, or John Terry, William Gallas, now [Virgil] van Dijk and [Ibrahima] Konate, the same centre halves play every week.
"There's a consistency with team selection, with that pairing at the back. Paris Saint-Germain, same two centre backs, all the way through, bang, winning the trophy.
"Consistency of players in that area of the pitch gives you a better chance to win. This chopping and changing is just, I find it wild - I don't like it and I wouldn't like it if I played."
When asked about what affects a centre-half when coming on, Ferdinand added: "Your first one, two, three sprints you are absolutely hanging onto things, your lungs are on the floor, red raw.
"Getting into a game is difficult man, and they're just getting into that speed of the game and the rhythm of it, it's hard man."

headline: What Spanish media are saying about Marcus Rashford – real reason he was late and telling response
body: Marcus Rashford has been spared by the Spanish media after being dropped for arriving late to a pre-match meeting. Despite his superb match-winning brace against Newcastle in the Champions League last week, the on-loan striker found himself on the bench for Barca’s La Liga clash with Getafe on Sunday.

Rashford came off the bench at half-time and set up a Dani Olmo goal as Hansi Flick’s side strolled to a 3-0 home win. Since the game, it has been widely reported in Spain that Rashford was cut from the starting line-up after being two minutes late for a team rendezvous.

His tardiness has been attributed to filling out an electronic form, which the club requires every player to complete each day. The Manchester United loanee wasn’t late for the pre-match activation session, due to start an hour later, but Flick, a strict disciplinarian, insists any player who doesn’t arrive on time doesn’t start the following game.

Rashford isn’t the first player to be affected by the German coach’s team rules, with Jules Kounde, Inaki Pena, and, most recently, Raphinha being dropped for similar reasons. Rashford was reportedly due to start the Getafe game on the left side of Barca’s attack, but Ferran Torres got the nod instead.

His response to his omission was telling, though, with no suggestion that he sulked about being dropped. After replacing Raphinha at the break, Rashford impressed on the right side of the attack as well as laying on Olmo’s game-clinching third goal.

While the Spanish media has largely overlooked aside Rashford’s indiscretion, former Spain international Lluis Carreras wasn’t so lenient as he backed Flick’s methods. He said via SER: “I can’t imagine being late to a training camp. It shows the coach that you're not fully focused on the match.

“Since you haven’t been focused, I’ll give you half so you can stay involved in the game. Raphinha [who scored twice after coming on against Valencia] showed that with two goals, Rashford with an assist, and it seems logical to me.”
But it was all positive from Rashford after the game when he took to Instagram. “+3 points, vamos equipo [let’s go team],” he wrote with an image of himself in action.

When questioned about his decision to bench Rashford, Flick insisted he was managing the forward’s workload, saying: “For Rashford, it’s normal not to play. Matches are every three or four days. We have to manage his minutes.
“You saw that with Fermin. He played many minutes, and we have to take that into account. We got three points, 3-0. Everything is great. We must focus on our game.

“We scored three goals, and it's not always easy to score three goals against a strong team. I don't want to talk about the opponent; I want to talk about my team. We must focus on our game and our plan.” Barca, who are two points behind leaders Real Madrid, visit Real Oviedo on Thursday.

headline: Paul Scholes slams 'quitter' Marcus Rashford in scathing criticism as true feelings laid bare
body: Manchester United icon Paul Scholes has made an astonishing claim as he accused Marcus Rashford of 'quitting' after falling out of favour under Ruben Amorim. The 27-year-old got off the mark for the Catalan club in the Champions League with a brace that sunk Newcastle United last week.

The forward also chipped in with an assist during their weekend 3-0 triumph against Getafe, extending his impressive beginning since his latest temporary switch from Old Trafford. Rashford has returned to the headlines following his positive performances but it comes after his unceremonious exit after being cast aside under the Portuguese tactician.

Rashford expressed his desire to explore his options after spending the second half of last season on loan at Aston Villa. Late in the summer transfer window, his move to a Champions League club came to fruition.
His displays for Unai Emery's outfit secured him a recall to the England squad after slipping down the hierarchy under Thomas Tuchel's predecessor, Gareth Southgate.
While Scholes acknowledged Rashford's ability, he hammered the 27-year-old's mentality regarding his behaviour during his troublesome period with United.
"There's no doubt the talent that kid has got, it's ridiculous, he's shown up in a big game, and that second goal was brilliant," he said.
"I really struggled to feel happy for him, to feel pleased for him.
"Mainly because his attitude, his attitude at United. The time he was leaving, I thought it was just disgrace at United, not trying, basically.
"Look, if you fell out with a manager, then OK, but remember, you've got teammates you're playing with.
"You've got a massive 80,000 there, whatever it is, every single week that you have to put a bit of effort in.
"The amount of times I saw him at United walking because he wants to leave, I thought his whole demeanour was a disgrace.
"I think he actually quit on Manchester United. And once you quit once, you'll quit again."

headline: Ex-Man Utd star Anderson told he will go to prison for failure to pay child maintenance
body: Former Manchester United midfielder Anderson has been ordered to serve prison time over a reported failure to pay child maintenance. The 37-year-old has been warned he can be held behind bars for 30 days unless he hands over the £142,000 he is said to owe.
The decision was taken on September 3 by a family court judge in the retired footballer’s southern Brazilian home city of Porto Alegre but only emerged overnight.
Brazilian press say international Anderson, who won the Premier League four times with United after signing for the club from Porto in July 2007, will be confined to his cell.
He'll be closely supervised under a tough 'closed regime' if there is space for him in local jails unless he makes an eleventh-hour payment.

They are reporting he will be allowed out to study or do community work during the day, but have to return to his lock-up at night, under a more lax 'semi-open regime' only if there is prison overcrowding. The court decision is understood to be based on the alimony payments Anderson owed as of July 28.
The former footballer, who also played for Fiorentina in Italy and Internacional in his homeland before hanging up his boots aged just 31, has yet to make any official comment.

His lawyer Julio Cezar Coitinho Jr confirmed to local press the case involved minors but said he couldn’t comment because of a secrecy order. Anderson was said to be father to four children in 2015 and NINE children at the start of last year when he recalled his time at United in an interview with a Brazilian newspaper.
He revealed he and his former Portuguese team-mate Nani were “adopted” by Cristiano Ronaldo for nearly a year while they slept at his house, saying their beds were stretchers.

He said: “I thank him very much. He adopted me. We lived at Ronaldo's house for almost a year. We left because we wanted to leave. For him we could have stayed there. We didn't spend anything. The guy took us to training, fed us, had a cook for us. There was a swimming pool inside and outside the house, a jacuzzi, and a tennis court."

Anderson was capped eight times for his country. He made his Brazil debut during the 2007 Copa America, which they went on to win. He also played for the Brazil Olympic football team during the 2008 Summer Olympics in Beijing, helping them secure the bronze medal.

He scored his first goal for United in the Audi Cup friendly tournament against Boca Juniors in July 2009, two years after signing a five-year contract with the club to become its second Brazilian player after Kleberson.

Anderson signed a new four-and-a-half year contract with United in December 2010, switching to Brazilian club Sport Club Internacional on a free transfer during the 2014-15 season after falling out of favour.

headline: Man Utd star told to WALK OUT on team-mates in dramatic move to make his point
body: Rio Ferdinand claimed Benjamin Sesko may have to take a leaf out of Ruud van Nistelrooy's book and walk out of training if he wants his Manchester United team-mates to know what his demands are.

The Slovenian's goalless start to life at Old Trafford continued on Saturday as he fired a blank against 10-man Chelsea. Sesko was hauled off at half-time, which was not a glowing assessment of his performance, with the striker largely ineffective during his time on the pitch.

Sesko was signed for £74million and that price tag is set to hang over him until he finds the back of the net. Ferdinand couldn't believe his lack of involvement in what was a dominant first-half display for the Red Devils - in part owing to his lack of service.

The ex-United defender said on his Rio Presents podcast: "In the first half, against 10 men, he’s had six touches. Six touches! I think the responsibility goes to the striker as well [as other players].

"In today’s game there’s enough at your disposal technology-wise and clip-wise that you can get it in black and white on the iPad and say to your team-mates, ‘You know when you got in that position, look where I am.'"
Ferdinand referenced scenarios where Amad, playing out wide, had the opportunity to find Sesko but didn't.

As a result he's recalled how Van Nistelrooy, who scored 150 times in Manchester, once walked off the training pitch when Cristiano Ronaldo didn't cross him the ball to him and believes Sesko could benefit from a similar act.

He added: "It’s decision making in the final third that’s going to set him free or it isn’t, and he’s got to try and dictate to a lot of those players either through runs that make it so obvious or physically telling them after a game.
"They’re the type of conversations he has to have because I know Ruud [van Nistelrooy] was having that.

"I saw Ruud van Nistelrooy walk off the training field because Ronaldo did too many step overs and he wasn’t playing it when he wanted it. You’ve got to find it from somewhere to make your team-mates know, and that will be the making of him."
Sesko arrived with a reputation as one of Europe's best young strikers. He had impressed at RB Leipzig.
But so far in Manchester, Ruben Amorim has started him from the bench in three of his five games, albeit the 22-year-old has not furthered his case when he has started.

headline: Man Utd were close to signing World Cup winner who won Ballon d’Or
body: Brazilian legend Ronaldinho remains one of the most painful 'what if' stories in Manchester United's modern era. The Red Devils were tantalisingly close to landing the 2002 World Cup champion's signature in 2023, but a dramatic eleventh-hour U-turn saw the future Ballon d'Or recipient choose Barcelona instead.

The mesmerising attacker was allegedly mere days away from being unveiled as United's latest marquee signing during the club's pre-season American tour in the summer of '03. Yet even Sir Alex Ferguson's magnetic appeal couldn't compete with the irresistible pull of the Catalan giants.
Ronaldinho subsequently became the planet's finest footballer whilst in Spain. He claimed the Ballon d'Or in 2005 whilst securing two La Liga titles and the Champions League in 2006.

In his memoir, Sir Alex revealed precisely how near the Brazilian transfer came to completion. "I had agreed a deal to bring him to Old Trafford. Carlos Quieroz [United's assistant manager at the time] was there and would vouch for that," Ferguson wrote.

"The attempt to buy Ronaldinho reflected the fact that United have always sported talismanic players. I was always hunting for that kind of talent. My line of reasoning was, 'We're getting £25m for Beckham, and we're getting Ronaldinho for £19m. For God's sake, wake up. It was a steal."
Among them was former United midfielder Paul Scholes, who revealed he went from getting ready to welcome the then-PSG star to trying to tackle him in a friendly just days afterwards.

Speaking on Robbie Savage's Savage Social podcast, Scholes said: "We were away at pre-season and I think they were as close as announcing him and giving him the number, but he ended up changing his mind last minute and he signed for Barcelona.

"It's strange really because that pre-season tour we were playing against Barcelona, so we were all excited. We thought he was going to bring something special, almost like what (Eric) Cantona brought to the team. Then three days later we're playing against him in Seattle, so everyone's trying to kick him! We were trying to beat him because he didn't sign for us."
Ronaldinho told El Enganche in 2014 that boardroom changes at Barcelona, plus the club's track record of nurturing Brazilian talent, swayed his decision.

"Everything was beautiful and happened fast. A great friend of mine was about to become a part of the Barcelona board: Sandro Rosell," Ronaldinho said. "I was almost on my way to Manchester United and only the details needed to be put onto that deal. But in the last minute Rosell called me to tell me they would win the election. That made everything happen fast. I wanted to play in Barcelona.
"I had the opportunity to follow in the footsteps of my idols. I was proud to play where Romario, Ronaldo and Rivaldo had played and I had the chance to be Barcelona's new 'R.' I loved that."
While United may have missed out on Ronaldinho, Sir Alex soon after snapped up a young talent named Cristiano Ronaldo, and as they say, the rest is history.

headline: Man Utd news: Marcus Rashford response after Barcelona snub as Ruben Amorim sends clear message
body: Manchester United were able to savour their hard-fought 2-1 victory over Chelsea over the weekend. Ruben Amorim’s side were given an early gift after Chelsea goalkeeper Robert Sanchez was sent off but United were forced to fight for the win at Old Trafford after Casemiro’s dismissal at the end of the first half.

Amorim would have enjoyed his side earning an important three points as United aim to build momentum. After the Chelsea result, Amorim was asked about one of his predecessors after Jose Mourinho was appointed the new Benfica manager last week.

Meanwhile, United midfielder Kobbie Mainoo played a minor role in the club’s victory, replacing club captain and goal scorer Bruno Fernandes in the 87th minute. Former United defender Phil Jones has questioned Mainoo’s place in the pecking order and suggested that the England international could soon look to move on from the Red Devils.

One player who has already left Old Trafford is Marcus Rashford after sealing his loan move to Barcelona this summer. The La Liga champions have the option to make Rashford’s switch permanent for £26million and the England international demonstrated his ability with an impressive brace against Newcastle United last week.

Rashford may not have expected to start Barcelona’s 3-0 victory over Getafe on the bench after scoring a Champions League brace in his previous outing. The 27-year-old’s performance sent a clear reminder of what United are missing out on after agreeing to loan out the forward for a second time.

However, The Athletic reported that Rashford was not included in Barcelona’s starting lineup against Getafe after turning up late to training on the day of the match. His Barcelona team-mates Raphinha, Jules Kounde and Inaki Pena have all previously fallen foul of the same rule in the past.

Despite beginning the game against Getafe on the bench, Rashford quickly made up for lost time after replacing Raphina at the break. The United loanee took just 17 minutes to provide an assist for Dani Olmo as Barcelona completed the 3-0 scoreline as he provided the perfect response to being dropped to the bench.

For his part, Flick played down any sense of his team selection being because of a disciplinary issue. "For Rashford, it's normal not to play, matches are every three or four days. We have to manage his minutes,” he said. “You saw that with Fermin. He played many minutes, and we have to take that into account. We got three points, 3-0. Everything is great. We must focus on our game."

Ruben Amorim sent a clear message to Jose Mourinho after the former United boss was named Bruno Lage’s successor at Benfica. Amorim was linked with the Portuguese giants, where he spent much of his playing career, before Mourinho’s appointment. Following United’s win over Chelsea, Amorim credited Mourinho’s early successes for giving other Portuguese coaches, such as himself, the chance to get top jobs.

"He’s the best Portuguese manager, and that won’t change." Amorim told DAZN Portugal, as reported by A Bola . He’s always been a very special person in our football, but also in the world, and he opened all the doors for us.

"I wouldn’t be here if it weren’t for Jose Mourinho. I think it’s going to be a lot of fun for you in Portugal, and we’re going to enjoy it. But that’s the way it is, and we’ll be here, watching to see what happens, but focused only on Manchester, and that will be my only club."

Former United defender Phil Jones fears that Amorim’s reluctance to start Kobbie Mainoo could see the midfielder leave the club in the near future. Mainoo saw a loan request rejected during the final days of the summer transfer window, but the 20-year-old has made jus three substitute appearances in the Premier League, with his only start coming against Grimsby in the Carabao Cup.

"It just looks like at the minute he’s out of favour. The manager has already come out and stated he's not going to be playing with Bruno," Jones said of Mainoo’s situation on Stadium Astro. "It's going to be him or the other and you're not going to dislodge Bruno in the form that he's in and the way that he carries the team at times with his assists and goals.
"So, he's going to find it difficult for games and United aren't in any European competitions this season. There's not another competition that he might've got some game-time in.
"Time will tell, but I think by Christmas and January time, if he's not had the game time that he'll like, then I'm sure he will be trying to force a loan move."

headline: Chelsea news: Enzo Maresca's Alejandro Garnacho U-turn as new striker is snubbed by own fans
body: Chelsea will be hoping to return to winning ways against Lincoln City in the Carabao Cup tonight, after falling to a 2-1 defeat against Manchester United. The Blues were hit with disaster early on as goalkeeper Robert Sanchez was sent off in the first five minutes for a last-man foul on Bryan Mbeumo.

Bruno Fernandes and Casemiro fired United into a 2-0 in the first 45 minutes, before the Brazilian was also sent off after receiving a second booking for a foul on Andrey Santos. Trevoh Chalobah made it 2-1 on the 80th minute, but it ended in defeat in Alejandro Garnacho's first game back at Old Trafford.

Blues boss Enzo Maresca made some interesting substitutions throughout the game - likely due to his 'keeper's dismissal - with the Argentinian not making it off the bench against his old club. Midfield superstar Cole Palmer was also taken off early against United, as the Italian issued a fresh update on the England international's fitness as he struggles with a groin issue.

Meanwhile, incoming Chelsea striker Emanuel Emegha was snubbed by the Strasbourg fans after scoring the winner as captain at the weekend. Despite celebrating his strike in front of the supporters, many of the crowd looked less-than-impressed with his appearance on the pitch.
Garnacho returned to Old Trafford for the first time since his £40million switch to Chelsea in the summer - but he didn't make it off the bench.

As Chelsea chased an equaliser during the final 10 minutes, many would've thought that the Argentinian winger would've been brought on for his flash of pace and ability on the flanks. And this was part of the plan. However, despite receiving tactical instructions in the second half, Garnacho never made it onto the pitch.
Maresca has confirmed that this decision to snub the 21-year-old was down to the need to make substitutions elsewhere.
Speaking post-match, the Italian said: "Garnacho was ready to go, but then Wes [Fofana] asked for the change because he was tired after a long time so we decided to go for Malo [Gusto].
"But the idea was to give Garnacho minutes."
Garnacho's return to United was met with a hostile reception from fans, with a symphony of boos ringing out every time he made an appearance from the bench during warm-ups.
When asked if the poor atmosphere towards the youngster affected his decision to sub Garnacho on, Maresca shrugged off this notion and remained resolute in his first answer.
He said: "No, no, no. He was ready, I sent him for the warm up and he was ready but then Wes asked for the change so we decided to go with Malo."

Incoming Chelsea striker Emanuel Emegha dealt with his own troubles in a similar fashion to Garnacho at the weekend, despite scoring for Strasbourg on Sunday. The 22-year-old has agreed a seven-year deal with the Blues, but won't head to Stamford Bridge until 2026.

This means that the Strasbourg captain will remain with his current club - who function under the same owners as Chelsea - for the first half of the French season. However, this news hasn't been met with the best of responses from the fans, who have made their feelings known towards Emegha.

In the club's 1-0 win over Le Havre last week, the striker was left out of the starting line-up, but a banner still went up in the crowd slamming the star's Chelsea move. It read: "Emegha, pawn of BlueCo, after changing your shirt, give back your armband."

This distaste continued into Strasbourg's 3-2 win against Paris FC, where Emegha topped off his return to action with a goal, which was subsequently confirmed by VAR after being chopped off initially.

During the celebrations, the 22-year-old ran up to the away crowd and held his shirt up to them in a statement of intent. While some fans celebrated the goal, many could be seen looking unimpressed - which angered boss Liam Rosenior.
The 41-year-old said: "Emegha was devastated, and I was too. I am very disappointed by what I saw. Seeing banners against one of last season’s best players is unacceptable."

The sale of Emegha to Chelsea was brought forward due to UEFA rulings, as per L'Equipe. If the two clubs had ended up playing in the same European competition next season, then the transfer would've been blocked - but it seems that Strasbourg fans aren't bothered much about the legal inner-workings of the deal.

Maresca has issued a positive update to star player Cole Palmer ahead of the club's Carabao Cup tie against Lincoln City. The midfielder was taken off against United, in one of three substitutes within the first 20 minutes after Sanchez' red card and Fernandes' opener for the Red Devils.
The England international had previously struggled with a groin injury, and Maresca confirmed that this issue is unlikely to result in surgery.

Speaking ahead of the trip to the League One side, he said: "The medical staff, they didn’t mention to me about surgery until today. I don’t know if in the next days or the next weeks, but I don’t think so, to be honest."
However, it is likely that Palmer won't be in the starting line-up against Lincoln in midweek, with the Italian being able to rest some key players as they take on a lower-league side.

The Blues have two tough games coming up in the Premier League and in Europe. Brighton and Hove Albion will come calling on Saturday, before ex-Chelsea boss Jose Mourinho brings his Benfica side to Stamford Bridge in the Champions League.
It is most possible that Palmer will be looking ahead to these tests, with other fringe stars being handed opportunities in domestic cup fixtures as and when they come up.

headline: Man Utd receive new referee verdict after Casemiro red card vs Chelsea as ban set
body: Manchester United have been informed why the correct call was made to send off Casemiro during their weekend triumph over Chelsea.

The Red Devils secured a 2-1 win against the west London side in their Premier League encounter at Old Trafford on Saturday night. Bruno Fernandes and Casemiro found the back of the net for United in a match that saw both sides finish with ten players.

Chelsea goalkeeper Robert Sanchez was shown a straight red inside the opening five minutes following a challenge on Bryan Mbeumo just outside the box. Casemiro was shown a red card in first-half stoppage times after collecting two yellows for challenges on Enzo Fernandez and Andrey Santos.

The decision to give Casemiro his second caution has sparked discussion after referee Peter Bankes gave the United midfielder his marching orders. Now, ex-Premier League referee Dermot Gallagher has revealed why he thinks the right call was made

"The second one - people will say to me, 'Is it enough for a second yellow card?' I am forever saying not every tackle after a yellow card is a second yellow card, but the difference here is he has deliberately gone to pull him back.

"We see every week, we are saying 'Everybody who is pulled back gets a second yellow card'. People say, 'He [Casemiro] got the ball', he gets the ball because he pulls him [Santos] back. I think second yellow card, red card."
However, former Premier League striker Jay Bothroyd disagreed, arguing that Casemiro should not have been dismissed for his challenge on Santos. "I think that was harsh," Bothroyd stated.
"On the pitch, players know exactly what is going on. The player [Santos] has actually run across Casemiro, he can't get out of the way because he is running as well at speed.

"There is nothing you can do apart from maybe put your arms up and try and get out of the way. I think that is what he is trying to do there. I think that is really harsh to give him a second yellow there to send him off.
"I think that is really harsh because he is trying to get out of the way, there is nothing he can do there at all."

As a result of receiving two yellow cards, Casemiro will now serve a one-match ban, ruling him out of the Premier League match against Brentford this weekend. The Brazilian will be eligible to play again in United's home game against Sunderland on October 4.

headline: Man Utd make plans to sign 'top goalkeeper' despite Senne Lammens transfer
body: Manchester United will pursue a 'major goalkeeper' in next summer's transfer window after Ruben Amorim confirmed that neither Altay Bayindir or the club's most recent signing, Senne Lammens, are locked in as the team's No 1.

United responded by sealing an £18.2million deal for Lammens on the final day of the summer transfer window. However, the 23-year-old Belgian is viewed as a quality prospect for the future and is not guaranteed to play ahead of Bayindir, who looked more assured in Saturday evening's 2-1 win over Chelsea.

But despite spending a significant sum on Lammens just weeks ago, The Sun claim that United plan to bolster their goalkeeping options again next summer, with an elite shot-stopper on the club's wishlist with Onana moving to Turkey.

It remains to be seen who the Red Devils will target, though. They also weighed up a move for Emi Martinez before pressing ahead with a deadline day swoop for Lammens after seeing an audacious loan bid for the Aston Villa goalkeeper rejected earlier in the transfer window. It's understood he would have cost significantly more than Lammens, who is viewed as Belgium's next No 1 keeper.

Onana was signed for a fee in excess of £47m back in the summer of 2023 as the club decided to part ways with their long-term No 1, David de Gea. However, Onana has looked a shadow of the goalkeeper who starred for Inter Milan, making a string of errors during his time at Old Trafford.

Bayindir has also struggled to convince when deputising for Onana. He was at fault for the only goal of the game in United's 1-0 loss against Arsenal on the opening weekend of the new Premier League season but has been picked for all five league games so far this term.

"No, nobody has a place that is his place," Amorim said recently when he was asked if Bayindir was now United's first-choice keeper. "Everyone has to fight. Everyone is fighting for a place. I'm just trying to win games, trying to see what is the best option to win the next game.
"So, in the end of the season, maybe it's a different team on the pitch. We are just trying to win games. Trying to get the best connections to play better and, in the end, to win points."

headline: RAILSTON: Barcelona punishment for Marcus Rashford will not shock Manchester United
body: Marcus Rashford was talismanic for Barcelona in their Champions League win against Newcastle last week.
Then Rashford reported late for a team meeting and was dropped against Getafe. Rashford was only two minutes late, but Hansi Flick enforced a disciplinary rule that meant he lost his starting role.
Rashford might have been stuck in traffic or slept through his alarm. And it was just two minutes, but he is paid handsomely to do his job and should be able to follow Flick's rules at Barcelona.
Manchester United wouldn't have been shocked to hear of Rashford's punishment for being late to the meeting, as there have been concerns about his off-field behaviour in recent years.

Rashford was not axed from the club after a boozy jaunt to Belfast. Erik ten Hag was furious at the trip, but believed it would be detrimental to freeze Rashford out of his plans and disciplined him instead.
Ruben Amorim was not as forgiving when he saw something he did not like with Rashford in December. The academy graduate was dropped for the Manchester derby and sent on loan to Aston Villa.

Barcelona offered Rashford the perfect opportunity to breathe life into his career. Most pundits predicted that Rashford would be a success - La Liga is a weaker league and a change of scenery was expected to do him good - and his performance at St. James' Park was a reminder of his ability.

"I am not surprised," Flick said. "I think he's a fantastic player. His skills and finishing are unbelievable. I think also in the first half, he tried to create chances, but the finishing wasn't there.

"In the second half, it was. For a striker, it's always good to score. I am really happy. He is an important player. When we spoke before the season about what we needed in the team, we felt we needed a player like him. When we had this chance [to sign him], I said we have to do it. He's an outstanding player."

Flick added that Rashford's display had represented the "first step" and reiterated he needed to make "the next step." The German was hinting at consistency, but Rashford was denied the chance to build momentum due to his lack of punctuality.

Rashford came off the bench against Getafe for the second half to record an assist. His talent has never been in doubt, but Rashford must strive to become a model professional to get the best out of his career.
Amorim's stance on Rashford has ultimately been vindicated by the events of the last week.
Rashford sparkled against Newcastle, a fixture in his home country with millions of British eyes tuned in, but he needs to produce those displays each week.
It was brilliant to see Rashford in full flow against Newcastle, but everyone was thinking: where is this level every weekend? He is capable of so much but has struggled for consistency.
His failure to produce those consistent performances and concerns about his behaviour away from the pitch have prevented him from bridging the gap to become a world-class player.

Consistency is the hardest part of football, however, it shouldn't be difficult to follow club rules. Rashford's lateness shouldn't be blown completely out of proportion - it was only two minutes after all - but it's not the first time he's been disciplined.
He has been given a chance he cannot afford to waste at Barcelona. It would be a huge shame to see him squander an opportunity to kick on in his career because of more discipline issues.

headline: MCDONNELL: Amorim must achieve feat even David Moyes managed at Manchester United
body: It seems incredulous, as he approaches a year in charge of Manchester United, that Ruben Amorim has failed to win back-to-back Premier League games.
Amorim's record of nine wins from 32 Premier League games is pitiful, but of just as much concern is his failure to carry over the winning formula from those games into the next one.
Even David Moyes, who lasted just 10 months at United - the same length of time Amorim has been in charge - won back-to-back league games on seven occasions during his ill-fated spell in charge.

At Brentford on Saturday lunchtime, Amorim will once again try to string successive league wins together and build on the momentum and confidence gained from Saturday's gritty 2-1 win over Chelsea at a rain-lashed Old Trafford.
Victory at the Gtech Community Stadium in the early kick-off would propel United up to the dizzy heights of a top-five place, before the later games kick off.

More importantly, it would provide tangible proof of the progress Amorim claims to see every day in training, but has yet to be translated into matches in terms of consistency of results and performance.

After every league win under Amorim – and they have been hard to come by, let's be honest – it has been a case of one step forward, two steps back, a false dawn for United's manager, players and fans, with their ongoing failure to make winning a habit.

After a rousing 4-0 win over Everton in only his second game in charge, Amorim delivered his notable “a storm will come” soundbite and it did so three days later, as United went down 2-0 at title-chasing Arsenal.

Despite that defeat, hopes were high among United fans after their late smash-and-grab 2-1 derby win at local rivals Manchester City, but again they capitulated in their next league outing, humiliated 3-0 at home to Bournemouth three days before Christmas.

United had to wait until January 16 for their next win, a 3-1 triumph over Southampton, but reverted to type three days later, going down 3-1 at home to Brighton. Subsequent wins came over Fulham, Ipswich, Leicester and Aston Villa in the final game of the season, but none were backed up by another triumph.

Defender Luke Shaw was honest enough to admit United's lack of consistency has been their biggest failing, not just under Amorim, but his predecessors, and admitted the team have to start putting together winning runs if they want to start challenging towards the top end of the table again.

Shaw, speaking after the Chelsea win, said: “We spoke about it a lot this week - winning this game, winning three points and moving on to the next. The standard we have to set is how we did in the first-half. It's about being consistent and maintaining the levels, not just for 30 minutes or 45 minutes. It's where we need to get to if we want to be a top, top team at the top of the league.

“I felt like we were going to win. I think that's how we have to feel every game. We have to feel like we're going to go into the game and win. That doesn't matter who we play, home or away, we have to have that mentality every game – that we're going to win. We've got to go into games with that mindset.”

Shaw was spot-on in his assessment of United and the mentality they need to develop if they are to become a successful team again. But actions speak louder than words and on Saturday in west London we will discover if Amorim's players can turn rhetoric into results and achieve back-to-back wins under him for the very first time.

headline: MCDONNELL: United have a new starter as Ruben Amorim handed timely boost
body: Of the five changes made by Ruben Amorin in Manchester United's 2-1 win over Chelsea, that of Harry Maguire was perhaps the most curious.
Maguire, restored to United's starting line-up in the Premier League for the first time this season after three sub appearances, was replaced by Leny Yoro after 70 minutes at Old Trafford.
United boss Ruben Amorim gave no specific reason afterwards for the change, but given it was Maguire's first start this season, it is safe to assume he was replaced to protect him from injury.
Amorim has spoken often about the dangers players face in games when they enter the “red zone” and are more susceptible to injury, hence why he makes so many in-game defensive changes.

Given Maguire was immense on Saturday in the centre of United's three-man defence, with Matthijs De Ligt and Luke Shaw equally impressive either side, those within the stadium were understandably puzzled by his withdrawal with 20 minutes plus added time remaining.

But Amorim's thinking in making the switch was clearly to protect Maguire, who has surely now cemented his place in the United manager's first-choice back three, along with De Ligt on his right and Shaw on the left, after his rousing display against Chelsea.

Yoro may have started all four of United's Premier League games until the weekend, but he struggled in the abject 3-0 derby defeat at Manchester City the previous weekend, which is why Maguire came back into the starting line-up.

Maguire's towering display, complemented by the equally dogged and disciplined performances of De Ligt and Shaw, makes it unlikely Amorim will want to change his three centre-backs for Saturday lunchtime's trip to Brentford.

One Maguire moment on Saturday, as the swirling rain fell on a filthy night, drew nearly as big a cheer as both United goals. With five minutes to go until half-time, Maguire chased down a 50-50 ball with Chelsea's Joao Pedro and got to it first, sliding across the turf to send it emphatically out of play and clear the danger.

The clearance drew a huge cheer from United fans, with the decibel level increased when Maguire picked himself back up off the turf and purposefully but subtly barged into Pedro as he ran to get back into position, sending a clear message to the Chelsea striker that he was not to be messed with.

The aggressive clearance and belligerent barge into Pedro demonstrated Maguire's confidence on Saturday, something he has struggled with at times during his turbulent six-year United career, but which now looks restored, allowing him to produce his best form.

Maguire's aggressive and focused approach was shared by De Ligt and Shaw, the former making a vital last-ditch clearance to block a cross with Chelsea pushing for an equaliser, the latter making an equally important recovery tackle on Andrey Santos to halt a dangerous breakaway late on.

Before the Chelsea game, Maguire was presented with a framed shirt and pictures to mark his 250th appearance for United, which came with his substitute appearance in the derby loss at City six days earlier.

The milestone underlines Maguire's enduring value and importance to United, despite his much-maligned status outside of the club. As well as his defensive reliability, Maguire has proved effective at the other end of the pitch, plundering 16 goals, including six in the 89th minute or later, three of them winners and one last-gasp equaliser.

At a time when United need stability, aggression and balance at the back, Maguire's return to the side and his return to his imposing best could not have come at a better time as Amorim seeks to win back-to-back Premier League games for the first time since taking charge.

headline: MCDONNELL: Ruben Amorim handed chance to prove he meant what he said about Man United star Kobbie Mainoo
body: The time has come for Ruben Amorim to put his faith in Kobbie Mainoo.
United are five games into the new Premier League season and Mainoo has yet to start any of them, the midfielder having played just 76 minutes coming off the bench.
An unused substitute in the first two league games, Mainoo's only start was in United's humiliating EFL Cup exit to League Two Grimsby.

Even when Amorim deviated from his preferred central midfield pairing of Casemiro and Bruno Fernandes for the 3-0 derby defeat at Manchester City, dropping the former, Mainoo was overlooked, with Manuel Ugarte getting the nod ahead of him.

The irony of that decision is that when Mainoo eventually did come on at the Etihad Stadium, just after the hour mark, he brought more energy and mobility to United's midfield, underlining the folly of Amorim's decision to start the hapless Ugarte over him.

Now, with Casemiro suspended for Saturday's lunchtime trip to Brentford following his sending off in Saturday's chaotic 2-1 win over Chelsea at Old Trafford, Amorim has a major selection dilemma in midfield - whether to start Mainoo or Ugarte.

Given Amorim has insisted he will continue to deploy skipper Fernandes in a deeper midfield role, despite it not playing to his attacking strengths, it seems a straight choice between Mainoo and Ugarte as to who partners him in the middle.

Given Mainoo is not a holding midfielder and defensive duties are not second nature to him, it seems inevitable that Amorim will go with Ugarte for the trip to the Gtech Community Stadium, to give United greater security and a ball-winning mentality in the middle.

Another option would be to play both Mainoo and Ugarte in central midfield, but given Amorim's reluctance to play Fernandes further forward and therefore displace one of his first-choice front three of Bryan Mbeumo, Matheus Cunha and Benjamin Sesko – all big-money summer signings – that scenario seems unlikely.

Mainoo's desire to go out on loan before transfer deadline day, because of a lack of playing time, was entirely understandable, even if it gave the impression of a player with a questionable mentality, unwilling to prove himself and meet the challenge to fight for his place.

At 19, Mainoo started England's Euro 2024 final defeat to Spain but was not even included in Thomas Tuchel's latest Three Lions squad because of his outcast status at United. In a World Cup year, Mainoo's fear that he will miss out on next summer's tournament in the US is entirely justified, if Amorim continues to overlook him.

The Brentford game, therefore, is the perfect platform for Amorim to show he means it when he says he “believes in” Mainoo as a player, even though he has pointed out the young prodigy still has to improve in many areas, not least in his defensive mindset, tracking back and positional discipline.

But on Saturday, with Casemiro unavailable and Mainoo relishing the chance to start a first league game of the season, Amorim has the opportunity to change the dynamic of United's team. Given Amorim's pragmatism and unwillingness to change from his formation and personnel, Mainoo is primed for more disappointment, but starting him may be the bold step that can finally kickstart United's season.

Barcelona now play again on Thursday night, and the forward has shared photos of himself from their training session on Tuesday.
"Focus mode," Rashford's caption reads.
United teammates, past and present, have liked the post, including Aaron Wan-Bissaka, Andre Onana, Antony, Brandon Williams, Diogo Dalot, Ethan Wheatley, Joshua Zirkzee, Leny Yoro and Rasmus Hojlund.

It is the third time that Rashford has posted since the Getafe match. Hours afterwards, he shared photos from the match alongside the caption: "+3 points! Vamos equipo," the latter phrase translates from Spanish into English as "let's go team".

Then on Monday, he posted photos of himself at a restaurant by the beach with the caption: "Balance". In one photo, Rashford is holding a drink that caught the attention of David de Gea and Manuel Ugarte.

"Now you drink mate?" the former asked, referring to the herbal drink that is the national beverage of Argentina, Paraguay and Uruguay. Lisandro Martinez and Ugarte often drink mate before matches, with the former once teasing his teammates' ability to make it.

Alejandro Garnacho also commented in March on a photo of the latter holding a cup of mate while representing Uruguay on international duty: "Come on, brother, come back. I already need the morning mates."

headline: Harry Maguire launches strong defence of underfire Man United star after Roy Keane criticism
body: Manchester United centre-back Harry Maguire has leapt to the defence of Luke Shaw after he came underfire from Roy Keane following the defeat to Manchester City earlier this month. United were underwhelming in the Manchester derby, losing 3-0 to their fierce rivals. And, unsurprisingly after such a heavy loss, the critics were out in force to pick apart the Reds' failings.

One man who caught particular criticism from Keane was Shaw. The former United captain insisted the full-back, who is currently being utilised in a three-man defence, 'gave up' allowing Phil Foden to score. Addressing those criticisms after defeating Chelsea a week later, Shaw admitted: "I think people have opinions. Sometimes you just have to take it on the chin.
"He’s got a lot of experience, he was one of the best captains ever for Manchester United and, of course, it hurts. But for me criticism is part of being a football player.
"I listen to it, but I think he was right. Last week, I wasn’t at my level at all and I don’t need Roy Keane to tell me.
"After the game, I knew that. But of course it hurts."
Maguire is obviously no stranger to being criticised while playing for United. When he was captain, the Englishman was often mocked online, taking the criticism of him to a whole new level.
In an interview with United's official club website after surpassing 250 appearances for the club, Maguire defended Shaw.
"You don’t play at this club 250 or 300 times if you’re first and foremost not a good player," the centre-back explained.
"Luke’s an excellent footballer, and every manager that comes in, he gets questioned a lot. That’s what happens at this club.
"Every manager that comes in plays Luke, and there’s a reason why they play Luke, because he’s an excellent footballer, always has been and always will be."

headline: Why Manchester United are wearing unique third kit for Brentford thanks to Premier League rule
body: Manchester United return to Premier League action on Saturday afternoon when they travel to the Gtech Community Stadium to take on Brentford.

Following their slow start to the 2025/26 season, United will be hoping to have turned a corner after beating Chelsea at Old Trafford. Bruno Fernandes and Casemiro were on the scoresheet after Robert Sanchez was sent off early on.

Ruben Amorim's men travel to London for this weekend's lunchtime kick-off, looking to earn a first win at Brentford since January 2022. Fans who attend the game or watch on television will notice that United will look slightly different.

For the first time this season, they will debut their black third kit. So far, they have worn the red home shirt in all six competitive fixtures and only played in the white away kit during pre-season.

The strip's black base includes yellow and blue details, nodding to the away kit worn between 1993 and 1995. However, at Brentford, United will wear a unique kit to comply with the rules on kit clashing.
Ordinarily, the kit would contain black shirts and shorts to match the shirt. However, the Reds will wear yellow socks for this game due to Brentford's black shorts and socks.

It's a similar move to what Arsenal had to do when they travelled to Athletic Club in the Champions League last week. The Gunners' away kit contains dark blue and back with the shorts and socks the same colour, but they were forced to wear white socks and shorts due to them clashing with Athletic's home strip.

Premier League rules state that "when playing in league matches the players of each participating club shall wear a strip which is of a sufficient contrast that match officials, spectators and television viewers will be able to distinguish clearly between the two teams."

headline: BREAKING: Former Man United boss Ralf Rangnick remains in hospital as 'further treatment required'
body: Former Manchester United manager Ralf Rangnick reportedly requires treatment on an infection caught during a hospital stay after an injury to his right ankle.

German media reports his extended stay is because of a 'serious' reason. However, Rangnick, who is now the manager of Austria, is still expected to be on the side-lines for their two World Cup qualifying matches in October.

It's understood by German outlet BILD he underwent surgery at the trauma clinic in Murnau, Bavaria. They also claim he has caught a "hospital-acquired germ" which has to be "treated with further measures."

Rangnick is expected to remain in the hospital to undergo treatment on the infection. While he is expected to be well enough to manage Austria during the international break, he will reportedly not be present at their next squad announcement.

Instead, it's been claimed his assistant manager Lars Kornetka will announce the squad for their next matches against San Marino and Romania on October 9 and October 12 respectively. As a result of the numerous surgeries to his ankle, Rangnick has found walking difficult and was seen cycling the distance between the dressing room and the bench during Austria's recent clash against Bosnia.
